The Imperial *Complete Library of the Four Treasuries*
*Masters Section, Fourteenth Division*

*Comprehensive True Meaning of the Zhouyi Cantong Qi*
*Daoist Category*
*Abstract*

We, your ministers, respectfully note: *The Comprehensive True Meaning of the Zhouyi Cantong Qi* in three juan was compiled by Peng Xiao of Later Shu. Xiao, styled Xiuchuan, was a native of Yongkang who styled himself Zhenyi Zi. He served Meng Chang as Chaosanlang, holding the position of Yuanwailang in the Ministry of Rites, and was granted the Purple Gold Fish Bag. Details of his life remain obscure. Yang Shen’s preface to the ancient edition of the *Cantong Qi* identifies Xiao as a Daoist. Considering that during the reign of Wang Jian, Du Guangting was once appointed to office as a Daoist, it is plausible that Xiao was also a Daoist, though the source of this information is unknown.

The *Biographies of Divine Immortals* by Ge Hong states that Wei Boyang authored the *Cantong Qi*, a work in three juan on the mutual generation of the Five Phases, which ostensibly expounds the *Zhouyi* but in fact employs hexagram imagery to discuss the principles of elixir-making. Confucian scholars, unfamiliar with the art of divine elixirs, often annotate it in terms of yin-yang theory, thereby missing its true essence.

Upon examination, the text frequently employs the method of "receiving the celestial stems" (nayin) to expound the essentials of kan (☵) and li (☲), water and fire, dragon and tiger, lead and mercury, using yin-yang, the Five Phases, and the timing of dusk and dawn as indicators for advancement, retreat, and practice. Later works on alchemical furnace techniques all regard this book as their progenitor. The *Sui Shu: Bibliographic Treatise* does not record it, while the *Old Tang Shu: Bibliographic Treatise* first lists the *Zhouyi Cantong Qi* in two juan and *Zhouyi Wuxiang Qi* in one juan, erroneously classifying them under the Five Phases category, which deviates from their original purpose.

Xiao’s preface states that Boyang first presented the text to Xu, an Attendant Officer in Qingzhou, who then concealed his name and annotated it. During the reign of Emperor Huan of the Han, it was transmitted to Chunyu Shutong of the same commandery, thereby circulating in the world. However, those who transmitted its secrets were rare—perhaps this account is plausible. The *Tongzhi: Bibliographic Treatise* by Zheng Qiao later established a separate category for the *Cantong Qi*, listing nineteen annotated editions totaling thirty-one juan. Today, most of these are lost, with only Xiao’s edition surviving. It is divided into ninety chapters to correspond with the yang number nine, while the "Song of the Cauldron and Vessel," with its fragmented verses difficult to divide into chapters, is preserved separately at the end to correspond with the water number one. Additionally, Xiao composed the "Illuminating Mirror Diagrams and Secrets," appended to the end of the lower juan.

Xiao’s own prefaces, both preceding and following the text, elucidate its meaning in great detail. Among all annotated editions of the *Cantong Qi*, this is the earliest. During the Jiajing reign of the Ming, Yang Shen claimed that an ancient text of the *Cantong Qi* was unearthed from a stone casket in the south, purported to be Boyang’s original version, and asserted that Xiao’s edition had confused the text and commentary. Those fond of novelty often believed this claim. However, Zhu Xi’s *Investigation of Discrepancies in the Cantong Qi* follows the chapter sequence of Xiao’s edition. The *Cantong Qi* text included in the *Yongle Encyclopedia* also entirely adopts Xiao’s version, incorporating the annotations of Yu Yan and others beneath it. This demonstrates that Xiao’s edition, transmitted from the late Tang period, has a clear lineage of transmission. The version propagated by Yang Shen likely belongs to the same category as Feng Fang’s *Ancient Great Learning*—utterly absurd and unworthy of credence. Therefore, in compiling the annotated editions of the *Cantong Qi*, we still place this edition at the forefront.

Respectfully submitted for imperial review in the ninth month of the forty-sixth year of the Qianlong reign.
*Chief Compilers:*
*Minister* Ji Yun
*Minister* Lu Xixiong
*Minister* Sun Shiyi

**Preface to the *Zhouyi Cantong Qi Tongzhen Yi***

According to the hagiographies of the Perfected Immortal Wei Boyang of *Shenxian Zhuan*, Wei Boyang was a native of Shangyu in Guiji. Born into a family of hereditary officials, he alone declined office, cultivating the True and dwelling in reclusion, nurturing his will in emptiness and nonbeing. His literary talents were vast, his writings profound, and he was well-versed in apocrypha and divination. Serene and unadorned, he adhered solely to the Dao, regarding courtly robes and carriages as mere husks. It is unknown from which master he received transmission, but he obtained the ancient text *Longhu Jing* and fully grasped its profound principles. Thereupon, he condensed the *Zhouyi* to compose the *Cantong Qi* in three chapters. Feeling that its subtleties were not yet exhausted, he further wrote the *Busa Yituo* to supplement omissions. Expounding the arcane mysteries of the *Dan Jing*, his descriptions often employed allegory, borrowing events to conceal and reveal, using variant texts to subtly instruct. The Attendant Officer of Qingzhou, Xu, then concealed his name and annotated it.

By the reign of Emperor Huan of the Later Han, Boyang once more transmitted it to his fellow townsman Chunyu Shutong, whereupon it circulated in the world. In composing the *Cantong Qi*, Boyang declared that the cultivation of the elixir shares the same path as the creative transformations of Heaven and Earth. Thus, he borrowed the imagery of the *Yijing* to discuss it, invariably employing the metaphors of ruler and minister to distinguish inner and outer. He narrated the hexagrams *Kan* and *Li*, directly pointing to the eternal lead, arranging *Qian* and *Kun* to establish the measure of the crucible. He illuminated the father and mother, linking them to beginning and end, uniting them as husband and wife to constrain their intercourse. He compared them to male and female, manifesting their generative power, analyzing them into yin and yang, and demonstrating their cyclical reversal through the dark and new moons. He coordinated them with the ascent and descent of the Dipper’s handle, aligning them with the cycles of the stars, dividing them by dawn and dusk, and harmonizing them with the clepsydra’s marks.

Thus, he took *Qian* and *Kun* as the crucible, yin and yang as its embankments, water and fire as the mechanism of transformation, the Five Agents as auxiliaries, true lead as the progenitor of the medicine, and the Mysterious Essence as the foundation of the elixir. *Kan* and *Li* became husband and wife, Heaven and Earth father and mother. The eight trigrams were deployed, the four seasons driven, the 384 lines of the hexagrams divided, and the fire phases circulated. The five planets and twenty-eight constellations were arrayed within the crucible, whereupon the Water Tiger lay concealed, its form lodged in *geng* and *xin*, turning toward the west; the Fire Dragon lay hidden, its body following *jia* and *yi*, revolving toward the east.

The *Yijing* states: "The sage, perceiving the intricacies of the world, models them after their forms and images, symbolizing their proper affairs." Boyang thus drew upon these images. Who but one of the utmost penetration could partake in this? He cleaved open the primordial chaos, split asunder the vast primeval mist, directly pointing to the numinous root of Heaven and Earth, designating it as the progenitor of the medicine. He clearly beheld the sagely mother of yin and yang, employing her as the foundation of the elixir. He revealed the origin of the One Qi’s transformations, disclosing the fundamental workings of the Great Foundry’s generation. Who but one of the utmost attainment could partake in this?

At times, he fixed the clepsydra’s marks, divided the solar terms, gathered yin and yang, and hastened the spirits and demons. He compressed the 3,600 breaths of the true qi, revolved the seventy-two seasonal nodes, and activated the sixty-four hexagrams’ tally of yin. The Celestial Pivot was in his grasp, the twenty-four solar terms’ fire of yang drummed at his command. The axis of Earth obeyed his heart. Heaven and Earth could not conceal the mechanism of creation; yin and yang could not hide the root of nurturance. Thus, the numinous transformations knew no bounds, and the generation of the pure and perfect was achieved. Who but one of the utmost clarity could partake in this?

The *Cantong Qi* states:
*"Within the primordial crucible of chaos, black and white align.
The Dragon Horse descends its essence; the Doe and Buck conjoin their qi.
Like frost on horse’s teeth, like jade in a dog’s maw,
Quicksilver dwells with the Maiden, cinnabar with the Infant—
Their forms distinct, the medicine’s essence finely revealed,
The elixir’s shape fully perfected, its latent workings manifest,
The signs of the unmanifest made plain."*

Who but one of the utmost sincerity could partake in this?

At times, he borrowed the imagery of the lines, embedding comparisons within events, yet dared not divulge the celestial mechanism, nor conceal the arcane principles. Thus, he unfolded his exposition without cease, elaborating repeatedly, unable to desist, and so completed the scroll. His aim was to expound the essential Dao, to guide posterity, and to spare the embodied beings of the world from becoming mere yin demons. Who but one of the utmost benevolence could partake in this?

Moreover, there are those who attain the Three Lights’ pervasive virtue, roam the Eight Extremes, ingest golden sand to transform their forms, and consume fiery mercury to refine their essence and spirit. Thus, their bodies become purely yang, their spirits dwell in the true abode, the Three Corpses are cast off, the Three Realms transcended, and they ascend to the Upper Clarity as Perfected Immortals. Who but one of the utmost refinement could partake in this?

Xiao’s division of the *Cantong Qi* into chapters and meanings was based on the principle of borrowing and metaphor. The text lacks consistent structure, its words diffuse yet its Dao correct, its affairs manifest yet its language obscure. Later generations debated it, each adopting their own perspective: some divided characters for discussion, others combined sentences for annotation. Thus, divergent streams arose, and beauty and ugliness proliferated. Those who sought to study it found it difficult to attain clarity. Since the debates over beginning and end differed, and choices led to undetermined right and wrong, I have now divided it into chapters and fixed its sentences, ensuring that the principles cohere and the meanings align with the text. I hope this will aid those in the alchemical tradition.

The four chapters are thus organized into two fascicles, comprising ninety chapters. Yin and yang are divided into nine sections, titled *Fenzhang Tongzhiyi*. The main text is written in red, while subsidiary meanings are in black, making them clearly visible.

The upper fascicle contains forty chapters, the middle fascicle thirty-eight, and the lower fascicle twelve. Within it is the *Song of the Crucible*, whose words and principles are interlinked, its phrases fragmented, making chapter division impossible; thus, it is preserved intact to correspond to the number of Water One, symbolizing the completeness of the elixir’s yin-yang numerology.

Furthermore, following the *Cantong Qi*, I have composed the *Mingjing Tujue* and appended it to the end of the lower fascicle, intending to further open the gateway to the *Cantong Qi*.

Xiao, having received transmission from his master for many years, devoted himself to it without concealment. This is called "completing the true meaning of the arcane text," and I humbly hope it may, in some small measure, be passed on to posterity.

*Preface by Peng Xiao, the True One of Flying Crane Mountain in Changli*
*Imperially Commissioned Complete Library of the Four Treasuries*
*Zhouyi Cantong Qi Tongzhen Yi, Fascicle One*
*Composed by Peng Xiao of Later Shu*

**Chapter One: Qian and Kun as the Gate of the Yijing**
*Qian* and *Kun* are the gate of the *Yijing*, the parents of all hexagrams. *Kan* and *Li* form their encompassing frame, turning the hub and aligning the axle. Before the Great Simplicity, the Great Void, and the Great Beginning, though they contained the utmost subtlety of emptiness, no signs had yet emerged. At the juncture of the Great Commencement, the Great Prime, and the Great Ultimate, there was the Primal Unity—chaos. Within it resided the essence of the True One, the beginning of Heaven and Earth, the mother of the myriad things. Once the One Qi took form, the Two Modes divided, and then there were *Qian* and *Kun*, yin and yang, the Three Powers and Five Agents, the myriad things and their manifold names.

Thus, pairing *Qian* and *Kun* as the warp and weft of Heaven and Earth, and moving yin and yang as the bellows-key of creation, *Qian* and *Kun* are established, and yin and yang course within them. Master Wei observed that refining the Golden Elixir of Returning Cinnabar shares the same path as creation, and so he borrowed the images of the *Yijing* to expound it. Without exception, all begin by gathering the primal qi of Heaven and Earth’s chaos and True Unity as their foundation, and take the essence of *Qian* and *Kun*’s subtle movements as their model. Following the numbers of *Kan*, *Li*, *Pi*, and *Tai*, they establish the dynamics of punishment and virtue, and seize the mechanism of yin-yang transformation to complete winter and summer. Yin arises after noon, and yang stirs at midnight; when movement begins, it starts with the yang nine, and when still, it follows the yin six—this is the great safeguard of elixir refinement.

Thus, *Qian* and *Kun* serve as the crucible and vessel, *Kan* and *Li* as their encompassing frame, water and fire as husband and wife, yin and yang as dragon and tiger, the Five Agents as the weft containing true essence, and the Three Powers as the warp gathering pure vitality. Cold comes and heat departs, circulating through the three hundred eighty-four lines; the hare rises and the crow sinks, ascending and descending over three hundred eighty-four days—all these transformations begin with the bodies of the two hexagrams *Qian* and *Kun*.

Hence it is said: *Qian* and *Kun* are the gate of the *Yijing*, the parents of all hexagrams.

**Chapter Two: The Four Hexagrams of Yin and Yang as the Bellows-Key**
The four hexagrams of yin and yang serve as the bellows-key, covering and enveloping the Dao of yin and yang—like a craftsman wielding the marking line, holding the reins and bit, aligning the compass and square, and following the tracks to regulate the exterior by the center. Their numbers are recorded in the pitch-pipes and calendars, with monthly nodes of five and six, warp and weft serving the sun, combining to form sixty. Hard and soft have outer and inner aspects.

In refining the Golden Elixir of Returning Cinnabar, within the crucible lies the Golden Mother and the Flowery Pond, also called the Golden Womb and Spirit Chamber. Here, the four hexagrams *Qian*, *Kun*, *Kan*, and *Li* serve as the crucible, medicine, and bellows-key—the pivot and bolt. "Covering and enveloping" means wrapping and enclosing. Thus, there are the yin crucible and yang furnace, the hard fire and soft tally, all following the sixty-four hexagrams in endless cycles, mutually employed. Within this, they move through the twenty-four solar terms, dividing the seventy-two pentads, compressing a year’s twelve months of qi into one month, and a month’s qi into a day and night’s twelve hours. They fix the water clock, divide the two watches, separate midnight and noon, align yin and yang, harmonize the dark and new moons, unite dragon and tiger, and accord with Heaven and Earth’s great numbers, matching the transformations of yin and yang. If control is not errant and movement not lost, then externally, the tally of yin and yang aligns, and internally, the bodies of dragon and tiger are born. Thus it is said: A skilled craftsman relies on the marking line without error; a capable charioteer holds the reins and bit without wavering, conforming to the compass, square, and tracks.

This metaphorically describes the adept’s regulation of fire times. The "five and six" of monthly nodes refer to thirty days; each day and night corresponds to one hexagram, totaling sixty. The four hexagrams *Qian*, *Kun*, *Kan*, and *Li* are the parents of the medicine, the pivot and bolt of the crucible and vessel—though not part of the day-and-night count, the *Cantong qi* broadly encompasses them, combining to form sixty-four hexagrams. "Warp and weft serving the sun" means the hexagrams and lines serve as the warp of daily use, while the weft refers to the numbers of pitch-pipes and calendars. "Hard and soft have outer and inner aspects" means yang hardness and yin softness, with water and fire, metal and wood mutually serving as outer and inner.

**Chapter Three: At the New Moon, *Zhun* Takes Charge of Affairs**
At the new moon, *Zhun* takes charge of affairs; by dusk, *Meng* is to be guarded. Each day and night corresponds to one hexagram, used in sequence. All movements of yin and yang’s ascent and descent, the fire numbers, follow the hexagrams and lines. Each day and night corresponds to one hexagram, with affairs beginning with the two hexagrams *Zhun* and *Meng*—*Zhun* at dawn, *Meng* at dusk—from which the sequence proceeds.

**Chapter Four: Before Reaching the Dark and Bright**
Before reaching the dark and bright, the end returns to the beginning. The celestial stems and branches serve as the measure; movement and stillness have early and late. "Before reaching" refers to the two hexagrams *Jiji* and *Weiji*; "dark and bright" refers to the dark and new moons, the alternation of yin and yang’s brightness and obscurity. "Celestial stems and branches as the measure; movement and stillness have early and late" means yang pertains to movement and yin to stillness. Within the twelve hours, early and late divide yin and yang’s ascent and descent, the fire numbers circulating endlessly, mutually employed.

**Chapter Five: Spring and Summer Rely on the Inner Body**
Spring and summer rely on the inner body, from *zi* to *chen* and *si*; autumn and winter attend to the outer use, from *wu* to *xu* and *hai*. The yang fire advances the tally from *zi* to *si*, where pure yang governs, and the inner yin seeks the outer yang. The yin tally retreats the fire from *wu* to *hai*, where pure yin governs, and the outer yang attaches to the inner yin. This is the principle of the inner and outer bodies, the pattern of flourishing and decline, beginning with *Fu* and ending with *Kun*—all determined by the images of the lines.

**Chapter Six: Rewards and Punishments Correspond to Spring and Autumn**
Rewards and punishments correspond to spring and autumn; dawn and dusk follow cold and heat. The line statements possess benevolence and righteousness, issuing joy and anger in accord with the seasons. Thus, they align with the four seasons and Five Agents, attaining their principle.

The qi of spring’s arising is called reward; the qi of autumn’s withering is called punishment. From *zi*, *chou*, and *yin* is spring; *mao*, *chen*, and *si* are summer—these are the yang fire times. *Wu*, *wei*, and *shen* are autumn; *you*, *xu*, and *hai* are winter—these are the yin tally times. Within the twelve hours, they move the fire tally, corresponding to these four seasons, Five Agents, dawn and dusk, cold and heat, benevolence and righteousness, joy and anger. The line images do not err by even a hair’s breadth, hence it is said: "Within the crucible, the four seasons are unharmed; within the images, cold and heat are as one—thus the elixir is surely achieved."

An ancient song says:
*The sage seizes the intent of creation,*
*Grasping sun and moon, placing them in the furnace.*
*Gently stirring, the essence of Heaven and Earth rises,*
*Gathering yin and yang, the spirit-souls of sun and moon flee.*
*Whoever recognizes this is a true immortal—*
*Refine it, ingest it, and after a thousand days,*
*The body, free of yin, cannot die.*

Thus, in refining the Golden Elixir of Returning Cinnabar, if one does not model Heaven and Earth’s creation, following nature’s principles, there is no other way.

**Chapter Seven: Heaven and Earth Establish Their Positions**
Heaven and Earth establish their positions, and the *Yi* moves within them. Heaven and Earth are the images of *Qian* and *Kun*; "establishing positions" means arranging the positions of yin and yang’s pairing. The *Yi* refers to *Kan* and *Li*. *Kan* and *Li* are the two functions of *Qian* and *Kun*. These two functions, without fixed line positions, circulate through the six voids, coming and going without fixed abode—neither above nor below, neither constant nor hidden. Transforming within, they envelop the myriad things, serving as the warp and weft of the Dao.

"Heaven and Earth establish their positions" means the crucible of *Jiji* models *Qian* and *Kun*. "The *Yi* moves within them" means the tally of yin and yang, *Kan* and *Li*, and the fire circulate within. The crucible models *Qian* and *Kun*, and within it, the Golden Mother is placed to complete the Three Powers of Heaven, Earth, and Humanity. "*Kan* and *Li*’s two functions have no fixed line positions" means externally, water and fire are applied, their movements and stillness unfixed, thus circulating through the six voids, coming and going, above and below without constant position. Sometimes hidden, sometimes manifest, sometimes used, sometimes latent, they become the source of transformation and the mother of generation and completion. Hence it is said: They serve as the warp and weft of the Dao.

**Chapter Eight: From Non-Being to Being**

**Chapter Eight: Governing Being with Non-Being**

The utility of vessels lies in their emptiness, thus advancing the waxing and waning of *Kan* and *Li* until they vanish. Non-being is the dragon; being is the tiger. Non-being is the yang *qi* of mercury; being is the yin essence of lead. Lead and mercury reside within the empty vessel yet cannot spontaneously generate transformation. Through the ascent and descent of *Kan* and *Li*, propelling the four seasons, generation and completion become manifest. This is the use of an empty vessel to govern being with non-being. The ancient text *Longhu Jing* states: "Being and non-being restrain each other. When the Vermilion Bird flames into emptiness, yin arises and yang retreats; when yang stirs, yin recedes. With each waxing and waning, *Kan* and *Li* vanish and reappear in accord with the seasons."

**Chapter Nine: Words Are Not Idly Spoken**

Words are not idly spoken; discourse does not arise in vain. Verification, evidence, and efficacy are examined; the numinous is inferred; the structure of characters is traced to their principles as proof. *Kan*’s *wu* is the essence of the moon; *Li*’s *si* is the radiance of the sun. Sun and moon form the *Yi*, with hardness and softness in balance. Earth flourishes in the four seasons, weaving through beginning and end. Green, red, white, and black each occupy their quadrant, all receiving the power of the central *wu* and *ji*.

The sage does not idly fabricate empty words to delude later generations. Thus, he cites the verification of sun and moon, infers the efficacy of the numinous, distinguishes hardness and softness, points to metal and water as metaphors for dragon and tiger, models the movement of yin and yang to gather essence, completes the work with the five soils, and achieves fruition in the four seasons. Thereby, green, red, white, and black circulate, all receiving the power of *wu* and *ji*. *Kan*’s *wu* moon-essence is the moon’s yin; *wu* is yang—thus yin contains yang, symbolizing metal born within water: the tiger. *Li*’s *si* sunlight is the sun’s yang; *si* is yin—thus yang contains yin, symbolizing mercury born within fire: the dragon. Therefore, in refining the elixir, one gathers the essence of sun and moon, unites the numinous *qi* of yin and yang, and when the cycle of stellar revolutions is complete, the work of yin and yang concludes, returning all merit to talent and virtue, and the spirit and essence are perfected. "Inferring the structure of characters" refers to the *Yi* character, which images the sun and moon.

**Chapter Ten: The *Yi* Is an Image**

The *Yi* is an image. No image is more luminously manifest than the sun and moon. Exhausting the numinous to know transformation: when yang departs, yin arrives; converging like spokes at a hub, they revolve. Emerging and entering, rolling and unrolling, the *Yi* has three hundred eighty-four lines, each line extracting a tally. The tally refers to the sixty-four hexagrams. From darkness to dawn, *Zhen* arrives to receive the tally. At this moment, heaven and earth mate their essence; sun and moon mutually sustain. The male yang scatters its mystery; the female yin transforms into the Yellow Womb. Chaos intermingles, the root of authority is planted, the foundation is laid, and nurturing begins. The calyx congeals, spirit solidifies into form, and all creatures, even the wriggling and crawling, arise from this.

The *Yi* is an image, formed by the union of sun and moon. The Golden Elixir of Return likewise arises from the union of the sun and moon’s yin and yang essence and *qi*. Thus, the essence and *qi* of yin and yang emerge and enter, roll and unroll, circulating day and night in an endless cycle. Following the sixty-four hexagrams and their three hundred eighty-four lines, extracting tallies from each line, fire advances and retreats. When yin arrives, yang departs; when yang hides, yin acts. The *qi* of east and west intermingle; the sentiments of husband and wife harmonize. At this moment, *Zhen* arrives to receive the tally; heaven and earth mate their essence; sun and moon unite their souls and spirits. The chaos is the spirit-chamber, imaging the egg, its two halves merging like chaos. Within chaos, the yang dragon and yin tiger bear and respond to each other’s *qi*, planting the root, nurturing the calyx, until spirit congeals into form, ultimately becoming a refined entity. Thus, within the crucible-chamber is a heaven and earth unto itself. All wriggling and crawling creatures arise from this. The male yang belongs to heaven and is mysterious; the female yin belongs to earth and is yellow. This is the mutual employment of the old yang and old yin, the father *Qian* and mother *Kun*, at the extreme of the fire tally’s reckoning. Thus, within a single crucible, the transformations are manifest, each clearly imaging heaven and earth’s movement, giving rise to the myriad entities. If the fire-timing is lost, the withdrawal and addition are excessive, cold and heat do not correspond, or advance and retreat are misaligned, then by what seasonal nodes will heaven and earth generate entities? By what yin and yang will they produce dragon and tiger?

**Chapter Eleven: Thus Confucius**

Thus Confucius praised the vast chaos, the virtue of *Qian* and *Kun* pervading emptiness. Investigating antiquity, at the primal emperor’s time, the *Guan Ju* established the beginning. At the first marriage, *qi* intertwined, and the first year sprouted growth.

Confucius praised the *Yi*’s Dao, dividing *Qian* and *Kun* as the head of the myriad things, establishing *Xian* and *Heng* as the ancestors of husband and wife. Splitting the vast chaos, chiseling the chaos, he revealed the numinous form and communicated heaven and earth’s sentiments. Thus, the Dao of the five relationships—ruler and minister, father and son, husband and wife, male and female—was attained, and the mechanism of yin and yang’s great transformation was exhausted. *Qian* and *Kun* illuminated their pervading emptiness. Thus, Master Wei used the *Yi* as a metaphor to establish the crucible, moving the celestial mechanism to mate the forms of dragon and tiger and unite the bodies of husband and wife. Initially, there was no form or substance, as if within vast chaos. After the fire was kindled and the tally moved, the male and female essences intertwined. Thus, the mutual longing of the *Guan Ju*, the seeking of marriage, began at the fire’s inception, corresponding to the first year’s sprouting production. Day by day, month by month, the bodies of dragon and tiger were completed.

**Chapter Twelve: The Sage Does Not Arise in Vain**

The sage does not arise in vain. Observing earth, he manifests the celestial tally. The celestial tally advances and retreats, flexes and extends, responding to the seasons. Thus, the *Yi* unites the heart of heaven.

The sage Fuxi, gazing above and below, determined the *Yi*’s images and numbers, knowing the sentiments of the myriad things. He bequeathed this to later generations so that the unenlightened might understand the apertures of heaven and earth, steal the essence of yin and yang, recognize the root of transformation, and discern the forms of tally and response. Generation and conquest, advance and retreat, flexing and extending—all are within grasp. Thus, it is said: The *Yi* unites the heart of heaven. Therefore, he established images, gathered the utmost essence, prepared the crucible and furnace, moved the fire tally, followed the clepsydra, practiced the hexagrams and lines, fixed the hours, and divided the seasonal nodes to exhaust the great reckoning of heaven and earth.

**Chapter Thirteen: The *Fu* Hexagram Establishes the Beginning**

When the *Fu* hexagram establishes the beginning, the eldest son inherits the father’s body and founds the omen upon the mother. Waxing and waning respond to the bell and pitch-pipe; ascent and descent rely on the Dipper’s pivot. On the third day, dawn breaks, and *Zhen*’s *geng* receives from the west. On the eighth day, *Dui* receives *ding* from above, the upper half level as a cord. On the fifteenth, the *gan* body is fully replete. At *jia* in the east, the toad and hare’s essences—sun and moon’s *qi*—shine together. The toad observes the hexagram’s nodes; the hare’s essence emits light, generating seven or eight lines before bending, lowering, and descending.

When the *Fu* hexagram establishes the beginning, the eldest son inherits the father’s body and founds the omen upon the mother: the six yin lines below first transform into one yang line, forming the *Fu* hexagram. Thus, it is called "establishing the beginning." This refers to the *Kun* hexagram’s lower line transforming into a *Qian* line, its inner body becoming *Zhen*. *Kun* is *Zhen*’s pregnant mother, thus it is called "founding the omen."

*Zhen* is the eldest son of *Qian*, and from this, it gradually transforms with time until the fifteenth day, when it becomes pure *Qian*—the father. Thus it is said to "inherit the father’s body." This is also like the moon, which appears as a crescent on the third day and by the eighth day forms the upper half-moon, its yang number reaching half—an analogy for the cauldron’s metal and wood being evenly matched. By the fifteenth day, it is full and round, emerging in the east, where the toad and hare’s essences—sun and moon’s *qi*—shine together, an analogy for the cauldron’s metal and water reaching fullness through the proper firing.

Master Wei employs this hexagram’s imagery to illustrate the moon’s waxing: he condenses the half-month’s three *hou* into half a day’s six *chen*, advancing the yang fire and drawing forth the additions within the cauldron, where it receives the fire’s tally and undergoes these transformations, foreshadowing the sprouting. "Seven or eight lines having formed" refers to the fifteenth day, when the *Qian* body is fully realized. "Bending, lowering, and descending" refers to the subsequent text, where after the sixteenth day, the yang fire retreats and the yin tally is employed.

**Sixteenth Turning Receives the Mandate, Chapter Fourteen**
The sixteenth turning receives the mandate: at *xin*, dawn appears; *gen* aligns with the south at *bing*; the lower half-moon is on the twenty-third; *Kun* at *yi* on the thirtieth day in the northeast loses its light, its nodes exhausted, and the succession returns to the father’s body, the dragon reborn.

"The sixteenth turning receives the mandate" refers to the sixteenth day onward, when the yang fire first retreats and the yin tally begins to arise. "At *xin*, dawn appears" is like the initial advance of the yang fire, akin to the moon’s appearance on the third day. The lower half-moon on the twenty-third is analogous to the upper half-moon, with metal and water evenly matched. "*Kun* at *yi* on the thirtieth day in the northeast loses its light" signifies the yin tally’s complete dissolution and the yang fire’s exhaustion. Since within a month yin and yang are evenly divided, they succeed one another, just as water and fire mutually require. Once a month concludes, it reverts to the beginning, again employing the *Fu* hexagram to initiate the cycle. Thus it is said, "the father’s body, the dragon, is reborn."

**Ren and Gui Pair with Jia and Yi, Chapter Fifteen**
*Ren* and *Gui* pair with *Jia* and *Yi*; *Qian* and *Kun* encompass beginning and end. Seven and eight, nine and six likewise correspond; the four combine to make thirty. The yang *qi* wanes and vanishes, the eight trigrams array their luminaries, and the revolutions proceed without losing the center.

*Ren* and *Gui* are yin; *Jia* and *Yi* are yang. Their pairing refers to the elixir mother within the *Qian* and *Kun* cauldron, receiving the *qi* of the yang dragon and yin tiger in union. Thus it is said, "*Qian* and *Kun* encompass beginning and end." Seven and eight, nine and six combine to form the thirty days. Within these thirty days, seven and nine correspond to yang numbers, six and eight to yin numbers. *Qian* and *Kun* each claim half, and by the thirtieth day, both yin tally and yang fire are exhausted. Therefore, during the month’s firing cycle, one must follow the eight trigrams’ arrayed luminaries, revolving through *zi*, *wu*, east, and west, drawing forth and adding, ascending and descending, so that yin and yang unfold and contract, harmonizing metal and water. If the firing is mistimed, drought and flood disrupt the rhythm, undermining the principles of generation and completion, making it difficult to retain the dragon and tiger’s forms. Practitioners of the firing cycle must ponder this carefully.

**The Primal Essence’s Subtlety Defies Perception, Chapter Sixteen**
The primal essence is too subtle to behold; one infers its effects and verifies its signs. By observing its manifestations, one models its form, erects markers as standards, and divines auspices to determine fortune. Issuing commands in accord with the seasons, one must not miss the moment when lines shift.

Above, examine the *He Tu*’s patterns; below, recount the earth’s flowing forms. In the center, consult the human heart, aligning and assessing the Three Powers. When active, follow the hexagram’s nodes; when still, rely on the *tuan*’s words. Only after *Qian* and *Kun* are applied can the Way of heaven and earth be enacted—how could one not be cautious?

The "primal essence" is the cauldron’s divine spirit, the true essence, the primal *qi* of heaven and earth. Though it cannot be grasped or seen, it subtly follows the transformative mechanism, generating the myriad things. Being profound and elusive, one must infer its effects, verify its signs, and erect markers as standards. Issuing commands in response to celestial tallies, one gazes upward to observe the celestial patterns and downward to examine the earth’s principles, thereby uniting heaven and earth’s *hun* and *po*, harmonizing yin and yang’s contraction and expansion. Establishing the Three Powers, assessing fortune and misfortune, one follows the hexagrams’ images and the lines’ words, ordering ascent and descent by day and night. Thus *Qian* and *Kun* are at peace, husband and wife harmonize, dragon and tiger unite, and heaven and earth are ordered.

The foregoing discusses adhering to the clepsydra’s timing, circulating the fire tally, and clarifying the drawing forth and adding, advancing and retreating—each without missing the revolutions of the sun, moon, and stars. Only then does the cauldron’s interior, in accord with the four seasons, generate the myriad things’ divine essence. How could practitioners of the firing cycle not be cautious?

**The Governance’s Helm, Chapter Seventeen**
The governance’s helm: managing, sealing, and securing; opening, unfolding, and deploying the precious essentials. The *Kui*’s handle unifies the transformative net’s cords, the lines’ movements within foretell fortune or misfortune, while without, the five wefts arise, their interweaving and alignment responding to the times. When the four and seven fall into discord, the *Chen* and *Li* diverge, bowing and rising.

"The governance’s helm" refers to the practitioner of the fire tally’s sequential initiation. Once the metal is cast into the cauldron, one manages, seals, and secures it, ensuring tight closure. "Opening, unfolding, and deploying the precious" means the inner metal unfolds, its fluids flowing, with metal and water interdependent. Following the Dipper’s handle, one traverses the twelve *chen*, aligning the five planets among the four and seven (the four and seven being the twenty-eight lodges). If the weft’s signs are misaligned and the tally’s nodes do not correspond, fortune and misfortune arise from the lines’ movements, and the fire tally is lost in dawn and dusk. Thus, the outer five planets fall into disorder, and the inner five *qi* fail to harmonize. When the four and seven fall into discord, the encircling stars diverge, and the cauldron’s interior fails to generate. Though the outer fire moves, if the inner tally remains quiescent and unresponsive, the celestial *hun* and terrestrial *po* do not unite. Hence, the stars and planets fall into disorder, the sun and moon deviate, the four seasons lose their rhythm, and the myriad things fail to be produced—all due to the firing cycle’s mismanagement in summer and autumn, causing the cauldron’s interior to suffer irregular drought and flood.

**Wenchang Governs the Record, Chapter Eighteen**
Wenchang governs the record, interrogating and holding accountable the Three Ducal Ministers and the hundred officials, each overseeing their respective domains.

"Wenchang governs the record": the Dipper’s *Kui* bears the basket, and the six stars of Wenchang Palace are: first, the Supreme General; second, the Secondary General; third, the Noble Minister; fourth, the Controller of Destinies; fifth, the Controller of Emoluments; and sixth, the Controller of Calamities. The Three Ducal Ministers are the six stars beneath the *Kui*, paired two by two, called the Three Terraces, which govern the world. Above, they assist the Son of Heaven in ordering yin and yang and harmonizing the four seasons; below, they ensure the myriad things’ flourishing. They enable the ministers and grandees to fulfill their duties, just as the cauldron’s interior receives the *qi* of heaven, earth, and the myriad things, generating transformation.

When yin and yang fall into discord and the four seasons lose their measure, it is like the practitioner of the fire tally mismanaging the harmonization—hence the interrogation. The Golden Liquor’s Reverted Elixir’s secret lies entirely in the two characters "fire" and "tally," which govern its beginning and end. Though one may obtain the true tally, the true fire is difficult to attain—how could it be lightly discussed? Thus, Master Wei broadly employs analogies, fearing that later generations might become confused.

**Chapter Nineteen: The Sun Unites the Essence of the Five Phases**

The sun unites the essence of the Five Phases, while the moon receives the regulation of the Six Pitch Pipes. Five and six make thirty degrees, and when the degrees are complete, they begin anew. From origin to end, the threads of survival and decay unfold: at times the ruler grows arrogant, overbearing, and transgresses the Dao; at times ministers turn treacherous and perverse, straying from the proper path. The waxing and waning of the *chen* and *wang* phases fall into discord, bringing misfortune and blame. Those who uphold the law reproach and interrogate the faults, leaving the ruler to bear the consequences.

"The sun unites the essence of the Five Phases" means that each month, once, it conjoins with the moon. "The moon receives the regulation of the Six Pitch Pipes" refers to the Metal and Water within the crucible, which each month receive half a month’s *qi* of the pitch pipes. (The twelve pitch pipes are divided between the sun and moon.) The sun, moon, and five planets weave their warp and weft to generate the myriad things—this is like the crucible receiving the *qi* of external yin and yang, the rise and fall of the *zi* and *wu* tally, and the circulation of the essence of the five planets, the union of the sun and moon’s purest essences. Fortune and misfortune follow one another; survival and decay continue in succession, cycling endlessly, beginning anew only to return to their end—this is the *kun* hexagram.

Its divine chamber, the yin essence, resides in the Central Palace, embodying the virtue of Earth and symbolizing the ruler. If the crucible responds internally but does not act independently, it is because the ruler’s arrogance causes tribute from the four directions to cease, while treacherous ministers cause the timing of the hours to err. The waxing and waning of the *chen* and *wang* phases, the loss of the new and full moons, the blight of the dark and crescent—all faults are attributed to the ruler. The ruler is the Metal essence and Earth virtue, the divine chamber; the ministers are the essence of the Five Phases, the Six Pitch Pipes, and the *qi*; the gains and losses belong to the practitioner of the fire tally.

Thus, the maiden flees, the Crimson Dragon bolts, and the divine essence departs—what then remains of the Golden Liquor to seek?

**Chapter Twenty: The Celestial Pole Receives the Correct Alignment**

The Celestial Pole receives the correct alignment, moving leisurely and entrusting matters below. The Hall of Light enacts governance, and the state suffers no harm. Within, one nurtures the self, abiding in tranquility and emptiness, returning to the origin and tracing back to the primordial radiance. The inner illumination shines upon the body; the *dui* is sealed and fortified, the numinous root stabilized. The Three Luminaries sink into obscurity, and the Pearl of the *zi* is nurtured. Though unseen, it is near and easily sought.

"The Celestial Pole receives the correct alignment, moving leisurely and entrusting matters below" means the divine embryo resides in the Central Palace, like the ruler abiding in the Hall of Light, akin to the North Star. The *qi* of yin, yang, and the Five Phases are the ministers. When ruler and ministers govern within as the North Star aligns at the center of heaven, the *qi* of yin, yang, and the Five Phases harmonize, the fluids of Metal and Water in the crucible chamber flourish, and the ruler nurtures the self in tranquility, entrusting to the spontaneous transformations of emptiness.

"Returning to the origin and tracing back to the primordial radiance, the inner illumination shines upon the body" refers to Metal’s ability to conceal brilliance and yet, by reflecting light, grow ever more luminous when fired. "Sealing the *dui*" means the *dui* opening—once the Golden Tiger’s numinous root is stabilized in the Central Palace, the crucible’s mouth must be firmly sealed. The true essence of the Three Luminaries is then drawn inward to nourish the Pearl of the *zi* and the numinous mercury—hence "the Three Luminaries sink into obscurity."

The Three Luminaries are the yang fire, the yin tally, and the Metal embryo, symbolizing the sun, moon, and stars. Externally, there are also Three Luminaries, distributed within the moments of movement and stillness, the exchanges of yin and yang, and the transformations of tally and fire—thus they are formed. Since both inner and outer possess the bodies of yin-yang transformation, their subtleties cannot be fully expounded here. At this stage, the mysteries are such that they can only be transmitted orally, not committed to writing.

When Metal and mercury transform within the crucible, their changes are unfathomable, beyond scrutiny. Yet if the celestial mechanism is employed to regulate and restrain them, aligning with the pivot of the cosmic pattern, then Metal and mercury dare not flee, and Dragon and Tiger achieve union—hence "near and easily sought." As the *Yin Fu Jing* states: "The cosmos is in the hand; the ten thousand transformations arise from the body."

**Chapter Twenty-One: The Yellow Center Gradually Penetrates Principle**

The Yellow Center gradually penetrates principle, moistening and reaching the skin and flesh. At first, it is upright; in the end, it is cultivated. The trunk stands, the branches take form—yet one may grasp it only to conceal it from the world, so none may know.

As the *Yi Jing* states: "The noble person, with the Yellow Center penetrating principle, abides in correct position within the body. Beauty resides within and flows to the four limbs, manifesting in affairs—this is the utmost beauty." This speaks of the Metal Tiger within the crucible, initially receiving the external yin and yang essences, gradually moistening the skin and flesh. Once it first receives qi, the sprout begins to grow; the branches and trunk are set upright, and in the end, the fruit is formed. It is an analogy for true Mercury of Metal Sand first sprouting buds.

The "one" is Water. As the Water Root and true Metal reside within the vessel, firmly sealed and concealed, ordinary people cannot know it.

---

**Chapter Twenty-Two: Supreme Virtue Acts Without Striving**

Supreme virtue acts without striving, not seeking through scrutiny. Inferior virtue acts, its function unceasing. When the upper is closed, it is called "having"; when the lower is closed, it is called "lacking." The lacking serves the having; above, the spirit-virtue resides. These two apertures emulate the Metal qi, each requiring the other.

"Supreme virtue" is Water above; "inferior virtue" is Fire below. Water and Fire conjoined—this is the meaning of Qian and Kun. Water above is ever still, acting without striving, abiding in yin, not seeking through scrutiny. Fire below is ever in motion, circulating through the twelve celestial stems, its function unceasing.

The "upper closed" is called "having"—the inner Water. The "lower closed" is called "lacking"—the outer Fire. The "lacking" serves the "having," for Fire circulates the qi of the four seasons and five phases to nourish the spirit-embryo. Thus it is said: "Above, the spirit-virtue resides." This refers to the spirit-embryo of Metal and Mercury. These two apertures emulate the Metal qi, each requiring the other—meaning the Water and Fire, the yin and yang qi, are interdependent, forming the divine medicine. There is no other path.

Master Wei expounds this chapter to clarify the great outline of the method and the direction of the divine medicine.

---

**Chapter Twenty-Three: Knowing the White, Guarding the Black**

Know the white, guard the black—spiritual illumination will come of itself. The white is the essence of Metal; the black is the foundation of Water. Water is the pivot of the Dao, its number named "one," the beginning of yin and yang. It contains the Yellow Sprout, the master of the five metals, the Northern River Chariot. Thus Lead is black without but holds golden radiance within—like a jade hidden beneath coarse cloth, a madman outwardly.

The white is Metal; the black is Water. Knowing the root of Metal and Water and using it as the foundation of the medicine, spiritual essence will naturally arise within the vessel. Thus it is said: "spiritual illumination will come of itself." White Metal is born of Water, becoming the divine vessel. The Water’s essence is unbroken, and the two natures of Metal and Water form the pivot of the Dao.

Water’s number is one—the beginning of Heaven and Earth, yin and yang, the five phases, and the ten thousand things. Water is one, Fire two, Wood three, Metal four, Earth five. "Containing the Yellow Sprout" refers to Metal and Water generating the Yellow Sprout. The "master of the five metals" is the Northern River Chariot. The River Chariot is Water and Fire—meaning the qi of Water and Fire circulate to generate the five phases.

Thus, "Lead is black without but holds golden radiance within" refers to unrefined Lead before it is transformed into White Metal, mixed within the ore. Outwardly black, it inwardly conceals golden radiance—like a madman wearing coarse cloth yet holding jade.

---

**Chapter Twenty-Four: Metal is the Mother of Water**

Metal is the mother of Water; the mother nurtures the child within the womb. Water is the child of Metal; the child conceals itself within the mother’s womb. The true person’s subtlety is as if present, as if absent—now sinking, now floating in the great abyss. Retreating, they disperse, each guarding their own domain.

"Water is born of Metal; Metal is the mother of Water"—Metal gives birth to Water yet is nurtured in form by Water. Thus, "the mother nurtures the child within the womb." "Water is the child of Metal; the child conceals itself within the mother’s womb" refers to Black Lead transforming and residing in the West as the White Tiger, the Metal embryo. Water contains Metal yet hides its essence within the Metal’s womb—this is true Mercury.

"The true person’s subtlety, each guarding their domain" refers to true Mercury, driven by the external tally-fire within the mother’s womb, now sinking, now floating, flying and hiding unpredictably—as if present, as if absent. Following the tally’s response, advancing and retreating, each guards its boundary and dares not transgress.

Master Wei expounds this chapter to deeply clarify the inner image—beyond the reach of seeing and hearing, the state of true essence’s elusive emergence and disappearance. How wondrous! How divine!

---

**Chapter Twenty-Five: Gathering the White Brilliance**

Gather the white brilliance, refine it into vermilion. Forging it forms an outer defense; the white within holds the true. Residing in a square or circle, an inch in diameter, they blend and restrain each other. Born before Heaven and Earth, majestic and exalted.

"Gather the white brilliance" refers to the initial movement, first taking White Metal as the foundation. "Refine it into vermilion" refers to the smelting process, next using blazing fire to form the red.

"Forging it forms an outer defense; the white within holds the true" means using White Metal as the divine chamber. "Residing in a square or circle, an inch in diameter, they blend and restrain each other" refers to the Metal embryo, shaped like the primordial chaos, crafted into upper and lower halves. The hollow center, square or round, an inch in diameter, holds the true Mercury. Once the two halves are joined, firmly sealed and impervious, yin and yang correspond without the slightest leak, nurturing the Dragon and Tiger. As the ancient song says: "Secure the navel-embryo without leakage; transformation occurs in an instant."

"Born before Heaven and Earth, majestic and exalted" refers to true Lead existing before the primordial chaos of Heaven and Earth. Lead obtains the One and first takes form; then Heaven and Earth, yin and yang, the five phases, and the ten thousand things gradually arise. Thus Lead is the father and mother of Heaven and Earth, the root of yin and yang. The sage gathers the root of Heaven and Earth’s parents as the foundation of the great medicine, assembling the pure essence of yin and yang as the substance of the Returned Elixir—its creation far beyond that of ordinary things.

At the beginning of elixir refinement, the root of Heaven and Earth is taken as the medicine’s root, the mother of yin and yang as the elixir’s mother. If one cannot generate Heaven and Earth, yin and yang within, it is not the path of the Golden Liquor Returned Elixir. If one uses substances produced after the existence of Heaven and Earth, yin and yang—such as the five metals, eight stones, plant ashes, morning dew, night frost, snowmelt, ice water, green salt, white brine, and various other things—how difficult would it be?

Those of like mind, ponder this deeply, and you will awaken. Thus, the later chapter says: "After ten thousand repetitions, the divine illumination may be glimpsed, or revealed to others."

---

**Chapter Twenty-Six: Beside the Walled Enclosure**

**Chapter Twenty-Six: Beside the Walled Enclosure**

Beside it stands a walled enclosure, shaped like Penglai’s fairy isle—encircling, sealed, yet open on all four sides. One lingers, guarding and defending, its defenses tight and firm, barring all that is wicked and perverse. Winding chambers connect, ever vigilant against the unforeseen. Thus, one need not fret over hardship, nor weary the spirit and qi. When the chamber is full, none can retain it. He who guards it prospers; he who loses it perishes. In movement and stillness, rest and repose, it ever accompanies the practitioner.

In the refinement of the Returned Elixir, there are the altar, furnace, crucible, and hearth, stacked and joined as in the shape of Penglai. All around, the four directions are open. Within the crucible lies the divine chamber, the golden womb, its winding passages interconnected. Within it, too, are the pivot and bolt, firmly sealing and barring wickedness to prevent the true essence from escaping. Only then can stray thoughts be avoided, and weariness dispelled. Though the defenses are secure and the essence fills the chamber, one must still regulate and move yin and yang, alternating their functions to retain and bind the true essence, bringing about transformation. If the fire-tally is misapplied, even with true essence within, it will still scatter and flee. All depends on harmonizing water and fire, guarding without lapse—only then can one surely flourish. Thus, the true essence’s movement and stillness, rest and repose, ever accompany the practitioner.

---

**Chapter Twenty-Seven: The Errors of Misguided Practices**

Those who practice misguided methods turn their gaze inward, lost in thought, pacing the steps of the Dipper and the lunar mansions, tracking the six jia stems by day and the yin paths by night. They suppress the nine and the one, disrupting the primordial womb, swallowing qi, and making their intestines rumble. They expel the upright and inhale external perversities, dividing day and night between waking and sleep, never resting. Their bodies grow daily weary, their minds confused, as if deranged. Their hundred vessels boil and surge, never settling into clarity. They dwell in earthen huts, erect altars, and morning and evening pay homage, offering sacrifices to spirits and demons. When they glimpse forms or hear voices in dreams, their hearts stir with emotion, their minds rejoice, believing their years will surely be prolonged. Yet suddenly, their allotted span ends, their bodies decay, and their bones lie exposed. In all their actions, they err and rebel, losing the pivot of the Dao. Such arts are many—thousands, even tens of thousands—yet all deviate from the Yellow Emperor and Laozi, twisting and turning, straying into the Nine Dark Realms.

The "twisting and turning, straying into the Nine Dark Realms" refers to the Master Wei’s admonition that people, failing to grasp the fundamental principle of the Great Dao, pursue the crooked paths of side doors. Thus, they engage in petty inner contemplations, tread the steps of the Dipper and the lunar mansions, and track the six jia stems and celestial stems—mere childish defenses, the first steps of deviation.

There are also those who practice the arts of "facing the scene and receiving qi," the techniques of the bedchamber—bending and stretching, grasping and sealing, holding the breath and swallowing saliva. From this, their qi becomes disordered, their spirit exhausted, their hun damaged, and their po withered. The yang spirit flees the palace, and yin thieves plunder the lungs and liver. Within and without, they assail each other; at yin and shen hours, they press upon one another. The seven po wander to the gates of death, the three corpses wage war in the eyes. The hundred vessels boil, the three fields collapse into chaos. They sought eternal life but instead harmed their own. How could they ever attain clarity?

Others erect altars and platforms, offering sacrifices to licentious spirits and demons, hoping to encounter the Dao and beg for extended years. Thus, demonic qi invades their essence and po, and perverse winds arise in their hearts. In dreams, they commune; in waking, they see forms and hear voices, believing longevity is within reach. Yet they do not realize that their fate lies in their own hands—thus, their allotted span shortens, and their bodies decay. Such practices are manifold, all left-handed paths. The more they strive, the more they stagnate; the faster they seek, the slower they progress. They rebel against the true, deviate from the correct, and violate heavenly principles. Falsely claiming to be high Daoists, they openly defy the Yellow Emperor’s texts and obscure the true canon, utterly losing Laozi’s safeguards. Thus, the Master Wei wished to steer people away from side doors, guiding them directly into the true Dao. Though misguided practices may yield minor achievements, in the end, none can escape death and decay. Only the Golden Liquor Returned Elixir, once ingested, reverses aging and restores youth. One attains the rank of True Person, sharing the same longevity as Heaven and Earth.

Thus, the following text states:
When golden sand enters the five viscera,
Mist scatters like wind and rain.
Its fragrance steams and reaches the four limbs,
The complexion becomes radiant and lustrous.
White hair turns black again,
New teeth sprout where old ones fell.
The old man regains his youth,
The aged woman becomes a maiden fair.
Transformed, they escape the world’s calamities,
And are called True Persons.

The *Huangting Jing* also says:
At one hundred and twenty years, one may still return.
Beyond this, cultivating the Dao is truly difficult.
Though one awaits the nine transformations and the eight jade elixirs,
The essence of the sun and moon,
To rescue the old and infirm,
One knows this method is the supreme path of ascending to Heaven in broad daylight.
This is now made clear.
